paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves tumor sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Efficacy Cohort (Combination)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combination therapy, pooled across repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Control Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls including vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle treatments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Retrospective Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, retrospectively analyzed based on prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status (43 vaccinated, 87 unvaccinated).

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
